title: Ex-VW chief charged over 'dieselgate' car scandal
text:
Berlin | Martin Winterkorn, the former Volkswagen chief executive, could face up to 10 years in prison after German criminal charges were brought against him over the "dieselgate" emissions scandal.

The move came as it emerged that rival carmaker Daimler was under investigation by German authorities on suspicion of continuing to fit emissions-rigging software to its cars.

Mr Winterkorn was formally charged with fraud and breaking German competition law. They are the first German criminal charges against him over the emissions rigging and the first to put him in direct legal jeopardy.

The former chief is already under indictment in the US but is highly unlikely to face trial there because Germany does not extradite its citizens.

Mr Winterkorn resigned as VW chief in 2015 over the dieselgate scandal, in which cars were fitted with software designed to cheat emissions tests.

Prosecutors in the city of Braunschweig brought charges against him and four other former VW managers.
description: Mr Winterkorn is accused of lying to authorities and offering guarantees that VW was not selling rigged cars 'even after he knew about the illegal manipulations'.
